content:
I came across https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.15571 by @Tristan Simas , it looks like a big-if-true effort to formalize notions about (co)NP-completeness in Lean. It's odd, though, for one the paper includes almost zero Lean code (only 10 lines, in Appendix A), and largely discusses what seem to be nonstandard ideas about how complexity theory relates to e.g. the nature of specifications and economics.

The actual code is available only as attached to the arxiv zip upload, as far as I can tell, and has a bit of LLM smell:

/-- A polynomial-time reduction between decision problems -/
structure PolyReduction (A B : Type*) [SizeOf A] [SizeOf B] where
  /-- The reduction function -/
  f : A → B
  /-- The reduction is polynomial-time computable -/
  poly_time : ∃ (c k : ℕ), ∀ a : A, sizeOf (f a) ≤ c * (sizeOf a) ^ k + c

looks like an idea maybe related to kernelization, but nothing about poly-time, for instance.

yea, no. this is not a polynomial-time reduction. this is just "the result of f is small relative to its imput". it says nothing about computational complexity. i agree with your assesment that it has LLM smell.

the notion of decision problem they use is not the computability/complexity theory one, but (i think) some game-theory definition?

/-- A decision problem consists of:
  - A: Type of alternatives (decisions/actions)
  - S: Type of states (world configurations under uncertainty)
  - U: Utility function mapping (alternative, state) to real value -/
structure DecisionProblem (A S : Type*) where
  utility : A → S → ℝ

interestingly, they also seem to have a correct notion of polynomial reduction:

/-- Polynomial-time many-one (Karp) reduction between problems on encoded types.

    A reduction from A ⊆ α to B ⊆ β is a polynomial-time computable function f : α → β
    such that x ∈ A ↔ f(x) ∈ B.

    The "polytime constructible" requirement is captured by `PolyTime ea eb f`,
    which is `Nonempty (Turing.TM2ComputableInPolyTime ea eb f)`.
    -/
def ManyOneReducesPoly
    {α β : Type} (ea : FinEncoding α) (eb : FinEncoding β)
    (A : Set α) (B : Set β) : Prop :=
  ∃ f : α → β, PolyTime ea eb f ∧ ∀ x, x ∈ A ↔ f x ∈ B
they just don't seem to use it in their main theorems anywhere.

Well it’s a little complicated because, yes the notion of decision problem is not the complexity theory one, but they use that “decision problem” to construct an actual complexity theoretic decision problem (sufficiency check etc). The reductions seem plausibly correct on first pass to me.

That said, yeah this definitely reads like entirely LLM generated text with minimal human editing. Lots of grandiose claims with unclear referents (I’m not even sure what the research question here is). The “On the nature of definitional proofs” appendix screams unfiltered LLM output.

Thank you all for taking the time to read this so carefully. I used LLMs extensively and won't pretend otherwise. I clearly missed some critical details. I really appreciate you engaging with the math despite the problems. I've updated the appendix to show the correct reduction definitions and clarified what Lean proves versus what follows from standard results. The revised version is on Zenodo now and arXiv shortly. Grateful for your patience and feedback.
